the-importance-of-financial-literacy.title: The Importance of Financial Literacy
the-importance-of-financial-literacy.description: This unit introduces teachers and students to key concepts in financial literacy as they begin to engage with personal finance curriculum.

lessons.title: Basics Of Financial Decisions
objectives: Investigate financial literacy role models and influencers and evaluate whether influencers are trustworthy sources for financial education and advice.
Define financial literacy by listing characteristics of a financially literate individual.
Apply basic financial literacy concepts to real world scenarios and make personal connections to the content.

lessons.title: Financial Decisions
objectives: Identify healthy spending behaviors and habits differentiating between essential needs and discretionary wants.
Assess personal money management style by citing evidence from personal financial decisions.
Design a personal short-term and long-term financial goal considering both immediate and future priorities.

lessons.title: Responsible Financial Decisions
objectives: Define the psychology of money, listing examples of thoughts and emotions that can accompany beliefs about money.
Analyze common marketing and advertising tactics, such as AIDAR, and the influence of external factors on impulsive spending behaviors.
Create a plan that applies emotional self-regulation to financial decision-making such as the PACED framework, prioritizing an individual’s needs and goals.

lessons.title: The Importance of Financial Literacy Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from The Importance of Financial Literacy unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about The Importance of Financial Literacy.
Complete the 10-question assessment for The Importance of Financial Literacy unit.

paying-for-college.title: Paying for College
paying-for-college.description: This unit explores the costs associated with advanced degrees, available support for paying for college, and how to apply for these support channels.

lessons.title: Basics of College Costs
objectives: Assess the personal reasons individuals choose to go to a 2-year or 4-year college.
Research the differences in cost of public and private colleges.
Calculate the costs of the first year of college, comparing educational and non-tuition expenses.

lessons.title: Basics of Paying for College
objectives: Compare and contrast loans, scholarships, grants, and work study as ways to pay for college.
Evaluate sources of financial aid for a student, evaluating eligibility requirements.
Describe the value of scholarships and identify strategies for finding, applying for, and evaluating scholarship offers.

lessons.title: Understanding Student Loans
objectives: Differentiate between federally subsidized, federally unsubsidized, and private loans, listing characteristics of each.
Calculate the cost of college loans based on interest rate, amount borrowed, and loan term.
Describe how the process of applying for student loans can lead to success in management and repayment of the loans.

lessons.title: Applying for Student Loans
objectives: Define FAFSA and how it is used to apply for financial aid.
List the steps to completing FAFSA, identifying the information that is required to complete it.
Create a personal plan to complete the FAFSA setting deadlines for the process.

lessons.title: Paying for College Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from the Paying for College unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about Paying for College.
Complete the 10-question assessment for the Paying for College unit.

career-planning.title: Career Planning
career-planning.description: This unit explores options for career paths, advancing and changing your career, and how to get started with a side hustle.

lessons.title: Basics Of Career Planning
objectives: Compare post-high school options, weighing the pros and cons of each.
Create a career exploration plan by identifying goals, interests, values, and skills.
Describe intangible benefits that influence career decisions.

lessons.title: Considering a Job Offer
objectives: Assess personal values and priorities in the evaluation of job benefits offered by employers.
Differentiate between contributory and non-contributory benefits.
Evaluate competing job offers analyzing the benefits for each.

lessons.title: Advancing Careers
objectives: Analyze the impact of education levels on employment earnings, researching the costs and benefits of pursuing education or training.
Describe pay disparities and inequalities that exist for gender and race.
Identify personal strategies to balance “work-life” balance.

lessons.title: Changing Careers
objectives: Describe how changes in the job market can lead individuals to change careers.
Analyze the impact of technology, economic fluctuations, and market conditions on changes in the job market.
Evaluate your personal traits and proficiency in soft skills as consideration for career change.

lessons.title: Building a Side Hustle
objectives: Design a plan for pursuing a side hustle, listing the advantages and disadvantages of gig work.
Describe the costs and opportunities of starting a new business.
Create a business plan that outlines the business description, customers, and marketing focus.

lessons.title: Career Planning Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from the Career Planning unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about Career Planning.
Complete the 10-question assessment for the Career Planning unit.

economics.title: Economics
economics.description: This unit explores the basics of supply and demand, as well as the impacts of economic cycles on key aspects like inflation.

lessons.title: Basics of Supply, Demand, and Inflation
objectives: Demonstrate how the relationship between supply and demand impacts market prices.
Calculate change in inflation rates to show the impact on purchasing power.
Compare nominal and real returns to illustrate how inflation affects an investment’s return.

lessons.title: Economic Cycles
objectives: Describe the relationship between inflation and interest rates on savings.
Prove how saving with I bonds can protect against inflation and protect purchasing power.
Evaluate the positive or negative impact of inflation and interest rates on real-life personal finance scenarios.

lessons.title: Economics Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from the Economics unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about Economics.
Complete the 10-question assessment for the Economics unit.

taxes.title: Taxes
taxes.description: This unit explores the key terms associated with taxes and how to file your taxes.

lessons.title: Basics Of Taxes
objectives: Understand the primary purpose of taxes and everyday services that are funded by tax revenue.
Describe how income, payroll, property, and sales tax categories are structured.
Analyze the relationship between tax types, government entities that receive tax revenue and the impact of taxes on the individual.

lessons.title: Income Taxes
objectives: Differentiate between types of earned and unearned income sources.
Describe payroll taxes on earned income and their role in funding social programs.
Identify the taxes associated with unearned income to calculate net income.

lessons.title: Sales Taxes
objectives: Define sales tax as a percentage tax charged on the sale of certain goods and services.
Calculate the sales tax amount for a given purchase by applying the appropriate tax rate of various locations.
Distinguish taxable from non-taxable goods and the impact on the price of goods.

lessons.title: Filing Taxes
objectives: Explain how W-4 information impacts the amount of tax withheld from paychecks.
Analyze information from W-2 and 1099 forms to calculate taxable income, determine tax liability, and complete tax returns accurately.

lessons.title: Completing a 1040
objectives: Identify Form 1040 as the primary document used for filing federal income tax returns.
Determine the various types of personal, income, deduction, and credit information required to accurately fill out Form 1040.
Distinguish between federal and state income tax rates and their roles in determining overall tax liability.

lessons.title: Reducing Tax Payments
objectives: Distinguish between tax credits and deductions as strategies for reducing tax liability.
Evaluate the implications of refundable and nonrefundable tax credits for individuals and households.
Analyze how tax credits are incentives designed to encourage specific actions or decisions.

lessons.title: TurboTax Simulation
objectives: Analyze pay stubs and W-2 forms to accurately determine an individual’s income and tax contributions.
Utilize TurboTax to complete a tax filing, applying understanding of dependents, deductions, and refunds.
Assess the various roles tax revenue plays in supporting public services, infrastructure, and government operations.

lessons.title: Taxes Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from the Taxes unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about Taxes.
Complete the 10-question assessment for the Taxes unit.

banking.title: Banking
banking.description: This unit explores the basics of banking and common types of banking services.

lessons.title: Basics of Banking, Banks and Credit Unions
objectives: Describe the purpose of banks and define banking terminology.
Compare the advantages, costs, risks and services of commercial banks, investment banks, and credit unions.
Evaluate scenarios in choosing a bank, assessing whether a bank or credit union is a better choice for the individual.

lessons.title: Choosing a Checking Account
objectives: Describe the benefits and features of checking as they compare to other financial accounts.
Analyze transactions on a bank statement to demonstrate how to manage money with a checking account.
Explain how Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) regulates financial institutions and protects money deposited into a checking account.

lessons.title: Choosing a Savings Account
objectives: Calculate the return on a deposit using the factors of balance, interest rate, and time.
Describe the benefits and features of traditional savings accounts, certificates of deposit (CDs), and money market accounts.
Evaluate bank accounts to determine which best meet the financial needs of an individual.

lessons.title: Starting to Save Money
objectives: List the external influences and internal triggers that influence choosing to save or spend money.
Apply the 50/30/20 budgeting strategy to achieve savings goals.
Describe and identify market conditions that impact saving.

lessons.title: Banking on the Go
objectives: List advantages and disadvantages of online banking.
Differentiate between electronic banking, mobile banks, and mobile payments.
Identify the risks of online banking, describing strategies and actions that can be used to protect personal information and avoid financial fraud.

lessons.title: Banking Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from the Banking unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about Banking.
Complete the 10-question assessment for the Banking unit.

budgeting.title: Budgeting
budgeting.description: This unit explores the concept of budgets, how to create a budget and manage a budget over time.

lessons.title: Basics Of Budgeting
objectives: Identify key components of a budget: income, savings, investments, and expenses.
Explain how budgeting helps individuals achieve short-term and long-term financial goals.
Use a budget calculator to create a budget given various scenarios.

lessons.title: Preparing to Create a Budget
objectives: Identify the differences between needs (essential spending) and wants (desired spending) in the context of financial planning.
Apply knowledge of fixed, variable, necessary, and desired budget categories to assess an individual’s spending habits.
Evaluate a personal budget to identify potential for reallocations, savings, and informed spending decisions.

lessons.title: Developing a Budget
objectives: Determine gross and net income from a pay stub based on given information.
Analyze how prioritizing savings can help achieve short-term and long-term financial goals.
Develop a comprehensive monthly budget considering fixed and variable expenses, savings, and lifestyle preferences.

lessons.title: Making Changes to a Budget Over Time
objectives: Describe the value of an emergency fund in mitigating the effects of unforeseen expenses.
Create a budget that sets category spending limits to prioritize saving for emergencies.
Determine personal priorities for charitable giving.

lessons.title: Using a Budget to Make Financial Decisions
objectives: Apply budgeting rules, such as 50/30/20, to make informed spending decisions.
Develop strategies to reach savings goals by allocating budget resources.
Evaluate a given budget and propose practical adjustments that align to financial goals.

lessons.title: Budgeting Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from the Budgeting unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about Budgeting.
Complete the 10-question assessment for the Budgeting unit.

saving.title: Saving
saving.description: This unit explores how to save money, prepare for emergencies, and achieve financial goals.

lessons.title: Basics Saving
objectives: Understand various types of savings accounts: traditional, online, money market, CDs, and interest-bearing.
Identify fees and compare interest rates among different savings accounts.
Understand how state and/or federal regulation works and the importance of solvency regulation for financial institutions.

lessons.title: Saving for Emergencies
objectives: Describe the importance of building an emergency fund and determine when to use emergency savings.
Compare financial options for storing an emergency fund to ensure safety, accessibility, and growth.
Synthesize effective strategies to prioritize saving for an emergency and apply them to financial scenarios.

lessons.title: Saving for Retirement
objectives: Understand the purpose, benefits and limitations of the Social Security program for retirement planning.
Determine how pre-tax and post-tax savings vehicles and employer-sponsored plans can be used to achieve retirement goals.
Use a retirement calculator to evaluate progress towards retirement savings in given scenarios.

lessons.title: Saving for Other Long-Term Expenses
objectives: Compare Traditional IRA, Roth IRA, and 401(k) based on their tax benefits.
Analyze various benefits of education savings accounts, such as I-bonds, 529 plans, and Coverdell Savings ESAs.
Research the costs associated with healthcare and consider benefits of HSAs to manage healthcare expenses.

credit.title: Credit
credit.description: This unit explores the basics of credit, how to open and use credit cards and loans, and manage your credit over time.

lessons.title: Basics Of Credit
objectives: Describe the benefits of using credit responsibly to make a positive impact on personal finances.
Calculate the cost of using credit given the factors of: principal, interest rate, and time.
Compare installment, revolving, and service as different types of credit, providing examples of each.

lessons.title: Using Credit While Avoiding Debt
objectives: Explain the significance of credit history on an individual’s ability to borrow money, differentiating between good and bad debt.
Use a debt repayment calculator to evaluate the time and costs of repaying a loan based on given scenarios.
Assess an individual’s credit worthiness by calculating a debt to income ratio for an individual.

lessons.title: Establishing a Credit History
objectives: Explain the features and benefits of various types of credit cards, including how to use credit cards responsibly.
Define credit score, listing the factors that impact a credit score and the impact of a high or low credit score.
Describe how a credit report can be used to see how responsible an individual has been with credit, listing who can and cannot access an individual credit report.

lessons.title: Understanding Credit Scores
objectives: List the factors that impact a credit score and ways that an individual can increase their credit score.
Differentiate between a hard and soft credit inquiry, identifying the impact of an inquiry on a credit score.
Describe steps to remedy errors contained in a credit report.

lessons.title: Evaluating Credit Card Offers and Terms
objectives: Evaluate credit card offers by comparing the APR, fees, and benefits of each credit card.
Explain how reviewing a credit card statement can be used to manage finances and monitor debt.
Calculate the monthly payments, interest charges, and amount of time to pay off a credit card balance.

lessons.title: Loan Fundamentals
objectives: Compare the costs of borrowing using loans versus credit cards by calculating the monthly payments, total interest, and time required to repay debt.
Contrast between the loan categories: secured vs. unsecured, amortizing vs. non amortizing, and fixed rate vs. variable rate.
Evaluate competing loan offers, describing factors to consider when taking out a loan.

lessons.title: Auto Loans
objectives: Describe an auto loan as a secured loan, utilizing the terms: loan amount, loan term, value, and monthly payment.
Evaluate auto loans to choose a loan that offers the best terms.
Calculate the loan-to-value ratio of an auto loan, proving how a down payment makes a loan beneficial to both the lender and the borrower.

lessons.title: Mortage
objectives: Cite evidence to show how mortgages differ from other loan types, listing the features of mortgages including: loan term, interest rate, and loan process.
Calculate the down payment for a mortgage.
Compare monthly mortgage payments to choose the best mortgage for an individual.

lessons.title: Managing Credit and Debt
objectives: List the consequences of taking on bad debt or failing to repay unsecured and secured debt.
Differentiate between good debt and bad debt and describe strategies to use credit responsibly before taking on debt.
Compare four debt solutions: credit counseling, debt consolidation, debt settlement, and bankruptcy.

lessons.title: Alternative Credit Options
objectives: List types of alternative financial service providers, comparing the benefits, costs, and risks associated with each.
Compare a payday loan to a traditional loan by calculating interest cost and total costs of these two types of loans.
Prove how alternative financial service providers can lead to a debt cycle and give suggestions on how to avoid falling into a debt cycle.

lessons.title: Credit Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from the Credit unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about Credit.
Complete the 10-question assessment for the Credit unit.

investing.title: Investing
investing.description: This unit covers key terminology, how to build portfolios, and navigating markets and investment opportunities over time.

lessons.title: Basics of Investing
objectives: Define investing and how assets have potential to build wealth over time.
Distinguish investing from saving goals, considering factors such as time horizon, investment objectives, and risk tolerance.
Analyze the relative risks and potential returns of stocks, bonds, mutual funds, and ETFs.

lessons.title: Understanding the Risks of Investing
objectives: Analyze the impact of volatility, inflation, interest, liquidity, credit, and market risks on investments.
Investigate how the investment risk pyramid can be applied to different investment goals and risk profiles.
Evaluate the qualities of assets such as stocks and bonds in building a diversified and balanced investment portfolio.

lessons.title: Building an Investment Portfolio
objectives: Identify the properties that distinguish major asset classes, including stocks, bonds, real estate, speculative assets, and cash equivalents.
Understand the importance of building a balanced and diversified portfolio by incorporating a mix of asset classes with varying risk levels.
Describe the implications of time horizons for both short-term and long-term investing goals.

lessons.title: Pricing of Financial Assets
objectives: Identify factors that contribute to fluctuations in asset prices, including interest rates, inflation and market conditions.
Evaluate the impact of changes in the Federal Funds Rate on personal financial decisions, such as borrowing or investing.
Analyze how unemployment, consumer confidence, or industry events can potentially impact stock prices.

lessons.title: Earning a Return on Investment
objectives: Identify interest, capital gains, and dividend yields as different forms of investment returns.
Distinguish varying rates of return for various investments and apply the ROI formula to calculate nominal returns.
Synthesize real returns on investments considering the tax implications of short-term and long-term capital gains.

lessons.title: Hiring a Financial Professional
objectives: Identify the roles and qualifications of financial advisors.
Evaluate fees associated with financial advisors and their impact on investment returns.
Differentiate between financial advisors and various financial services providers, such as online brokerages and traditional brokerages.

lessons.title: Government Incentives and Protections
objectives: Analyze the impact of federal tax incentives on retirement savings within different IRA accounts.
Describe the responsibilities of key regulatory bodies in protecting investors and maintaining fair markets.
Explore the consequences of insider trading on individuals, companies, and broader financial markets.

lessons.title: Navigating Alternative Investment Opportunities
objectives: Describe the characteristics of speculative investments and identify the various markets where financial assets are traded.
Explain the concepts of cryptocurrency, NFTs, and blockchain and analyze their impacts on the financial market.
Apply investment strategies for purchasing speculative assets such as cryptocurrency and NFTs.

lessons.title: Using Technology to Manage Investments
objectives: Investigate the role of behavioral finance in investment decision-making.
Analyze the impact of management fees and costs associated on overall investment returns.
Evaluate the pros and cons of relying on technology for personal finance management.

lessons.title: Evaluating Investment Asset Performance
objectives: Explain how to use benchmarks such as the S&P 500 to assess the performance of an investment portfolio.
Explore the advantages of index funds as a low-risk investment option.
Analyze how expense ratios impact returns for active and passive investments.

lessons.title: Investing Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from the Investing unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about Investing.
Complete the 10-question assessment for the Investing unit.

insurance.title: Insurance
insurance.description: This unit explores the basics of insurance and common types of insurance policies.

lessons.title: Basics Of Insurance
objectives: Understand the importance of insurance as a way to mitigate and protect against potential risks and financial losses.
Define insurance premiums and explain the pros and cons of paying them based on individual needs.
Evaluate appropriate insurance policy packages based on personal risk profiles, life priorities and financial ability.

lessons.title: Auto Insurance
objectives: Explain how liability insurance protects drivers financially and how safe driving habits can lead to lower insurance premiums.
Determine how the cost of premiums and deductibles impact the coverage of insurance policies.
Apply knowledge of insurance package options, costs of premiums and deductibles, liability coverage to real-life driving scenarios.

lessons.title: Home and Renters Insurance
objectives: Analyze financial and non-financial factors when choosing to rent or buy, such as lifestyle, maintenance, and future plans.
Compare renters and homeowners insurance policies and evaluate which type of coverage fits different living situations.
Assess appropriate personal liability coverage based on real-life situations.

lessons.title: Health Insurance
objectives: Analyze the fundamental components and terminology of health insurance plans, policies, and medical bills.
Evaluate the costs and the benefits of health insurance in managing medical expenses.
Assess various health insurance options and determine the most suitable coverage based on individual needs and circumstances.

lessons.title: Life Insurance
objectives: Evaluate the importance of having adequate life insurance coverage to financially protect one’s family.
Compare types of life insurance policies and consider personal financial goals, family needs, risk tolerance, and budgetary constraints when choosing a policy.
Evaluate the necessity and benefits of life insurance in various scenarios by assessing relevant factors and personal circumstances.

lessons.title: Disability Insurance
objectives: Define the role of disability insurance in providing financial support when unable to work.
Examine disability coverage options and providers, considering personal needs and eligibility factors and apply to real-life situations.
Evaluate the impact of various disabilities on individuals’ lives and determine coverage options to mitigate financial risk.

lessons.title: Unemployment Insurance and Medicare/Medicaid
objectives: Describe the key features of unemployment insurance, including eligibility criteria, benefit calculation, and duration.
Evaluate government measures during economic downturns and their impact on reducing unemployment and supporting the workforce.
Compare medicare and medicaid as government-sponsored health insurance programs that provide healthcare access to target populations.

lessons.title: Extended Warranty Product Insurance
objectives: Explain how extended warranties function and identify the potential financial benefits and drawbacks for consumers.
Determine the cost-effectiveness of extended warranties by considering factors such as product price, warranty terms, and repair.
Predict future maintenance costs for various products and factor them into the warranty decision-making process

lessons.title: Insurance Fraud
objectives: Classify different types of insurance fraud and recognize potential fraudulent activities in real-world scenarios.
Analyze strategies to identify, prevent and report insurance fraud to minimize financial loss and prevent ongoing fraudulent activities for others.
Develop a plan of necessary actions and resources available to recover from insurance fraud.

lessons.title: Insurance Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from the Insurance unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about Insurance.
Complete the 10-question assessment for the Insurance unit.

money-mindsets.title: Money Mindsets
money-mindsets.description: This unit explores the principles related to consumer behavior and consumer fraud.

lessons.title: Basics of Spending Decisions
objectives: Evaluate personal purchases using product research, price comparison, and financial considerations, guided by decision-making frameworks like PACED.
Identify common advertising tactics and pricing strategies, and analyze their psychological impact on spending behavior.
Describe how inflation impacts the cost of certain goods, affecting consumer decisions.

lessons.title: Comparison Shopping and Negotiating Price
objectives: Differentiate between durable and non-durable goods, and understand their impact on purchase decisions.
Apply factors of goods such as durability, costs and product features to future consumer purchases.
Define effective negotiation tactics and evaluate the impact of negotiation on spending decisions.

lessons.title: Avoiding Scams and Fraud
objectives: Identify types of scams and fraud and describe the impact of falling victim to scams or fraud tactics.
Investigate the purpose of consumer fraud protection groups and explain how these groups protect consumers.
Evaluate ways to protect oneself from identity theft and apply strategies to protect personally identifiable information (PII).

lessons.title: Money Mindsets Unit Wrap Up
objectives: Reflect on learning by identifying key takeaways from the Money Mindsets unit.
Identify next steps to continue to build knowledge about Money Mindsets.
Complete the 10-question assessment for the Money Mindsets unit.
